pullRequest.body:
This file is based on Mathlib.Analysis.Calculus.Gradient.Basic, and describes the calculation properties

co-authored-by: Ziyu Wang [tropicalfish910@gmail.com](mailto:tropicalfish910@gmail.com)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Hi again! I looked very briefly at this file. Good job making these long inequality proofs compile! Thanks for putting in all the work. There may be a suitable generalisation of these theorems to (not necessarily reflexive) Banach spaces, but for a first attempt this may be sufficient. I found [this thread](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/111767/is-every-monotone-map-the-gradient-of-a-convex-function) that cites a paper that may be relevant. Perhaps you can start a thread on Zulip so that somebody more experienced can chime in!

As it stands, the file still needs some cleanup to be properly reviewed. I left some minor style comments, but the major work remaining is to somehow shorten all the long proofs. A lot of the `have` statements can probably be turned into `calc` blocks or `rw`s. Steps that can be extracted into separate lemmas should be done so liberally, as this is a primary way for mathlib to grow mature for future users. To help yourself and reviewers follow the proofs, please leave copious comments detailing the proof steps and marking places that seem needlessly tedious, which can of course be removed at the end. I've shortened 100-line proofs down to 30 just by revisiting them every other day to look for areas of optimisation. It's kind of fun.

When I find the time, I'll try to look at some of your steps and suggest how to golf them, but I hope you can try it yourself first. Happy coding/golfing!

Edit: General helpful tricks that I once received:
* Lean recompiles the proof from the start every time you change something in a subgoal, which can be a lot of waiting time for long proofs. Insert `save` just above where you're writing, so that the goal state is saved up to that point. When you edit below `save`, it will only compile from that point onwards.
* Lean seems to prefer a proof style that manipulates the goal using loads of trivial lemmas until it becomes simple enough to be closed by the assumptions. This means that, when you're tempted to write a new `have` statement, think either (1) can I rewrite or apply a lemma to the goal state instead, or (2) can I extract it into a separate technical/auxiliary lemma. This'll get rid of most of the nested `have` blocks.
* If you find yourself repeating proof steps in different places, that's the sign of a lemma!
* Unless the expression is unwieldy, avoid defining local variables. I see for example `a := 1 - b`, and then you prove `a + b = 1`. That's two lines you can shave off at the expense of writing `(1 - b) ‚Ä¢ x + b ‚Ä¢ y` instead of `a ‚Ä¢ x + b ‚Ä¢ y`, not a bad tradeoff.
* Try to use filters as much as possible. Mathlib really doesn't like epsilon-delta proofs, and I suspect you already felt the frustration from the lack of relevant lemmas. If you're thinking "I need a `Œ¥` close enough to 0 such that...", the canonical Lean statement is `‚àÄ·∂† Œ¥ in ùìù (0 : ‚Ñù), ...`. If you need `Œ¥ > 0`, use `‚àÄ·∂† Œ¥ in ùìù[>] (0 : ‚Ñù), ...`. See [nhdsWithin](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Basic.html#nhdsWithin) and [Chapter 9.1 of MIL](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathematics_in_lean/C09_Topology.html#filters). Extract an explicit `Œ¥` value as late as you can, using something like [Metric.tendsto_nhdsWithin_nhds](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/MetricSpace/PseudoMetric.html#Metric.tendsto_nhdsWithin_nhds) or similar lemmas in that file.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion {s : Set E} (h : ‚àÄ x ‚àà s, HasFDerivAt f (f' x) x)(h‚ÇÅ: Convex ‚Ñù s) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (h : ‚àÄ x ‚àà s, HasFDerivAt f (f' x) x) : ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (h : ‚àÄ x ‚àà s , HasFDerivAt f (f' x) x) : ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (h : ‚àÄ x ‚àà s, HasFDerivAt f (f' x) x) (h‚ÇÅ: Convex ‚Ñù s) ```
Did you mean `>` here for "strictly"? I would also suggest using backticks so that your formulas will render as code on the docs page. Or you can use LaTeX with dollar signs.

Using colon instead of brackets here. Isn't there also a convexity condition on the set `s`?
```suggestion
* First Order Condition for convex functions: function `f(x)` is convex if and only if for any `x, y ‚àà s`, `f(y) ‚â• f(x) + f'(x) (y - x)`.
```

Certainly good for clarity while you're coding, but when presented, we can remove these brackets because function type notation is right-associative.
```suggestion
variable {f : E ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {f' : E ‚Üí E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] ‚Ñù} {x y x': E} {s : Set E}
```

The separate spelling for `x` and `y` assumptions could be confusing. The following is much cleaner, especially when you already have a (y : E) declared above.
```suggestion
    (xs : x ‚àà s) (hy : y ‚àà s) : f x + f' x (y - x) ‚â§ f y := by
```

When writing predicates inline, you can shorten them by using the same notational trick as in `h` in the line above:
```suggestion
    (h‚ÇÇ: ‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ y ‚àà s, f x + f' x (y - x) ‚â§ f y): ConvexOn ‚Ñù s f := by
```

A trick I learnt recently:
```suggestion
  let g (t : ‚Ñù) := f (x + t ‚Ä¢ (y - x))
```

There are quite a few of these extra spaces throughout the file that you should remove eventually.
```suggestion
    (h‚ÇÅ : StrictConvexOn ‚Ñù s f) :
```

There's a nice tactic for precisely this. I would call the equality statement `hx'` or something starting with `h` instead of `x'rfl`.
```suggestion
  set x' := a ‚Ä¢ x + b ‚Ä¢ y with x'rfl
```

Use dot notation. Same goes for `Iff.mpr` used below in a couple places.
```suggestion
    have h‚ÇÅ: ‚àÉ Œµ1 > (0 : ‚Ñù), Metric.ball x Œµ1 ‚äÜ t := Metric.mem_nhds_iff.mp h
```

More dot notation
```suggestion
  have b_nonneg: 0 ‚â§ b := le_min b1pos.le zero_le_one
```

pullRequest.title: feat: monotonicity of gradient on convex real-valued functions
